# debugging

*this tutorial is not finished yet*

Functions frequently used for debugging purposes:

* `browser()`
* `traceback()`

### A simple example of browser:

```{r, error = TRUE}
my_function <- function(x) {
  print(x)
  stop("This is an error.")
  print(x + 10)
}
my_function(x = 2)
```

`{r}browser()` function:
```{r, error = TRUE}
my_function <- function(x) {
  browser()  
  print(x)
  stop("This is an error.")
  print(x + 10)
}
my_function(x = 2)
```
in order to quit `browser()`, type *Q* and hit *Enter*.


### A simple example of traceback:
(from R docs)

```{r, error = TRUE}
foo <- function(x) { print(1); bar(2) }
bar <- function(x) { x + a.variable.which.does.not.exist }
## Not run: 
foo(2) # gives a strange error
traceback()
## End(Not run)
## 2: bar(2)
## 1: foo(2)
bar
## Ah, this is the culprit ...

## This will print the stack trace at the time of the error.
options(error = function() traceback(2))
```
